title: 105_s2347
content: The Act may be cited as the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to prevent methamphetamine abuse by providing grants for school-based and community-based prevention programs. The funds provided under the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act must be used for planning, establishing, or administering methamphetamine prevention programs focused on high-risk populations in districts with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds prevention programs targeting high-risk populations in communities with high methamphetamine abuse rates. This includes assisting local government entities, training law enforcement officials, and conducting educational activities for prevention. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds prevention programs targeting high-risk populations in communities with high methamphetamine abuse rates. Grants are prioritized for areas experiencing high rates of methamphetamine abuse and addiction, with funding allocated for monitoring, evaluation, reporting, and pilot programs to encourage innovation. Not less than $500,000 is allocated for analyses and evaluation. The Director, with consultation from other agencies, receives at least $500,000 annually for analyzing prevention programs for methamphetamine abuse. Annual reports on program effectiveness are submitted to specific Senate and House committees. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the prevention programs for methamphetamine abuse, with $20,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 1999 and additional funds for each succeeding fiscal year. SEC. 3. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will create or amend federal sentencing guidelines for offenses related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine in violation of certain acts. The United States Sentencing Commission will adjust base offense levels for offenses related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine, increasing them by at least 3 levels above current levels or to level 27 if lower. The base offense level for an offense that poses a substantial risk of danger to another person, including law enforcement officers, will be increased by at least 6 levels or to level 30. The United States Sentencing Commission is granted emergency authority to promulgate guidelines or amendments for offenses below level 30. The amendments made shall apply to offenses occurring 60 days after the enactment of the Act. Increased resources are authorized for law enforcement. The Office of National Drug Control Policy is allocated $25,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 to combat methamphetamine trafficking in high intensity drug trafficking areas, with additional funding as needed for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. SEC. 4. Treatment of methamphetamine abuse. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment activities for methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The funds can be used for planning, establishing, or administering treatment programs specifically for methamphetamine. Amounts provided under this subsection can be used for evidence-based programs to help individuals quit methamphetamine use, training health professionals to recognize and treat methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The curr_chunk focuses on planning, administration, educational activities, monitoring, evaluation, reporting, pilot programs, and coordination related to methamphetamine treatment. The Director prioritizes grants for areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. Up to $1,000,000 is allocated for analyses and evaluations of treatment effectiveness and strategy development. The Director shall submit an annual report to specified committees with the results of the conducted analyses and evaluations. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding for succeeding years. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including studying its effects on the human body and addictive nature. The curr_chunk discusses various aspects related to methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including effects on individuals, connection to mental illness, prevention methods, treatment options, risk factors, effects on pregnant women and fetuses, and reasons for abuse. The Director will disseminate research results on combating methamphetamine abuse and addiction to relevant entities. $16,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding for succeeding years.
